{bc}leavened with yeast rather than with baking powder or baking soda

shortdef: having a pattern or design projecting from a background : done in relief
leavened with yeast rather than with baking powder or baking soda

cxtis.cxl: past tense and past participle of

dt: {bc}to cause or help to rise to a standing position
{bc}to recall from or as if from death
{bc}to set upright by lifting or building
{bc}to place higher in rank or dignity {bc}{sx|elevate||}
{bc}to end or suspend the operation or validity of
{bc}to breed and bring (an animal) to maturity
{bc}to bring up for consideration or debate
{bc}to increase the strength, intensity, or pitch of
{bc}to cause to rise in level or amount
{bc}to increase the amount of (a poker bet)
{bc}to make a higher bridge bid in (a partner's suit)
{bc}to multiply (a quantity) by itself a specified number of times
{bc}to bring in sight on the horizon by approaching
{bc}to cause (something, such as a blister) to form on the skin
{bc}to increase the nominal value of fraudulently
{bc}to articulate (a sound) with the tongue in a higher position
{bc}to scold or upbraid someone especially loudly

dt.t: new software that {it}raises the bar{/it} for competitors

pt: {sc}lift{/sc} {sc}raise{/sc} {sc}rear{/sc} {sc}elevate{/sc} {sc}hoist{/sc} {sc}heave{/sc} {sc}boost{/sc} mean to move from a lower to a higher place or position. {sc}lift{/sc} usually implies exerting effort to overcome resistance of weight.
{sc}raise{/sc} carries a stronger implication of bringing up to the vertical or to a high position.
{sc}rear{/sc} may add an element of suddenness to {sc}raise{/sc}.

pt.t: suddenly {it}reared{/it} itself up on its hind legs

pt: {sc}elevate{/sc} may replace {sc}lift{/sc} or {sc}raise{/sc} especially when exalting or enhancing is implied.
{sc}hoist{/sc} implies lifting something heavy especially by mechanical means.
{sc}heave{/sc} implies lifting and throwing with great effort or strain.
{sc}boost{/sc} suggests assisting to climb or advance by a push.

et: Middle English {it}reisen, raisen{/it}, from Old Norse {it}reisa{/it} {ma}{mat|rear|}{/ma}
shortdef: to cause or help to rise to a standing position

dt: {bc}brought to maturity or self-sufficiency through one's own efforts

dt.t: In the midst of a growing trend of absentee parents and {wi}self-raised{/wi} children …

dt: {bc}brought to maturity by oneself for one's own use or consumption

dt.t: Llamas are among the scores of animals on display at the fair. Young 4-H members show off their {wi}self-raised{/wi} livestock …

shortdef: brought to maturity or self-sufficiency through one's own efforts

dt: {bc}to engage in the organized activity of raising funds to support a cause, campaign, etc.

dt.t: He donated megabucks to all the trendy charities, and she served on the boards of everything. Perfect combination. He was generous and she was smart and well-organized. She could also {wi}fund-raise{/wi} with the best of them.
About $9000 has been {wi}fundraised{/wi} to cover the costs of flights with the Joss Group contributing $500 after Mrs. Michael appealed for help from Border businesses.

shortdef: to engage in the organized activity of raising funds to support a cause, campaign, etc.

dt.t: A high body-mass index is a {wi}red flag{/wi} in general to clinicians. But sudden, unexplained weight loss can be even more worrisome.

dt: {bc}something that indicates or draws attention to a problem, danger, or irregularity

dt.t: Interested large investors often send in their own CPAs to conduct complete audits to verify statements or to spot {wi}red flags{/wi}, such as excessively old inventory or uncollectible accounts receivable.

Whether you're dating a potential gold digger or are surrounded by friends who are constantly asking for handouts, you'll want to protect your money from those kinds of drains. Watch out for {wi}red flags{/wi} such as dishonesty, secrecy around money matters and requests to co-sign a loan.

Though Kearse did not take legal possession of the car until Jan. 4, 1999, after his eligibility had expired, the purchase {phrase}raised red flags{/phrase}. {gloss}=aroused suspicions of wrongdoing{/gloss}

shortdef: a warning signal or sign : something that indicates or draws attention to a problem, danger, or irregularity

dt: {bc}to raise (a poker bet) after it has already been raised by a previous player
{bc}to bet more than (a previous bettor who has already raised)

dt.t: {ldquo}… If I raise and he {wi}re-raises{/wi} me here, I'm going to have to fold the hand. …{rdquo}

dt: {bc}to raise a poker bet after it has already been raised by a previous player

dt.t: After Bortner folds, who else but Liebert {wi}reraises{/wi} to $24,000.

utxt.t: I thought a {wi}re-raise{/wi} would force him to fold, and I didn't want to lose him from this hand, because he had more than $20,000 in front of him.

shortdef: to raise (something or someone) again : such as
to raise (a poker bet) after it has already been raised by a previous player
to bet more than (a previous bettor who has already raised)

dt: used to say that something bad appears and causes trouble usually after not occurring for a period of time

dt.t: Inflation threatened to {it}rear its ugly head{/it}.
I knew that the leak we patched would eventually {it}raise its ugly head{/it}.

shortdef: —used to say that something bad appears and causes trouble usually after not occurring for a period of time

dt: {bc}a notion or fear of something bad that might happen in the future

dt.t: a nation alarmed/haunted by {it}the specter of{/it} famine/war
News of the disease {phrase}raised the specter of{/phrase} a possible plague.

shortdef: a notion or fear of something bad that might happen in the future
